title: The application of precision agricultural techniques to archaeological survey

tasks.task: Conducting archaeological surveys using precision agriculture and NDVI techniques.
subtasks: Researching historical and archaeological sources for the Roman road.
Verifying the course of the Roman road using historical maps and plans.
Conducting an exhaustive toponymic study of relevant place names.
Analyzing aerial photographs dating from 1972 to present for potential road locations.
Applying infrared camera technology via drones to capture near-infrared wavelength images.
Calculating NDVI index from drone photographs to assess crop health.
Comparing NDVI results with historical images to identify potential archaeological features.
Identifying cut features (white in NDVI images) and non-growing areas (dark) indicative of paved roads and ditches.
Verifying findings with contemporary ground-level observations (e.g., excavations for gas pipes).
Mapping identified features and comparing them to historical conjectures.
Evaluating the effectiveness of the NDVI method for archaeological remains.
Documenting positive and negative results for various sections of the Roman road.
Interpreting anomalies that may indicate additional archaeological structures.

tasks.task: Sharing feedback as a satisfied user of the precision agriculture technique for archaeological research.
subtasks: Expressing satisfaction with the solution provided for the Roman road location problem.
Describing the outcome of the experiment, including validated sections and new discoveries.
Highlighting the potential of infrared and NDVI techniques for extensive and intensive archaeological research.
Acknowledging the success in solving a historically complex problem for Alaba's heritage.
